Description: Alerts occurring during hours of expected inactivity indicate leaks, valve failures, or unauthorized water usage.
Short rationale: Encodes “should be inactive” windows; nighttime anomalies reveal absence/occupancy and possible unauthorized use.

Description: Repeated anomalies at the start of the day correlate with high-demand appliance or fixture use.
Short rationale: Captures morning peak routines and high-demand fixtures/appliances.

Description: Differences in anomaly frequency across weekdays infer variations in occupant activity patterns.
Short rationale: Reveals work-week vs weekend activity patterns and lifestyle rhythm.

Description: Increased anomalies during hot seasons suggest heightened water use or pipe stress.
Short rationale: Mostly indicates climate-driven usage or pipe stress, weak per-person linkage.

Description: Long anomaly intervals imply continuous flow from pipe bursts or stuck valves.
Short rationale: Long high flow shows bursts/stuck valves; property risk more than behavior.

Description: Brief spikes indicate appliance cycle changes or pressure shocks.
Short rationale: Brief spikes tied to cycles/pressure shocks; mild appliance/usage hint only.

Description: Repeated anomalies at identical times suggest scheduled systems like irrigation.
Short rationale: Fixed-time anomalies (e.g., irrigation) encode precise schedules of automated use.

Description: Clusters of alerts indicate progressive system failure or cascading events.
Short rationale: Clusters show progressive system failure; no meaningful behavior profiling.

Description: Flow spikes before high-use periods may reflect pressure buildup or regulator faults.
Short rationale: Pre-high-use spikes mostly speak to pressure/regulator faults, weak behavioral link.

Description: The speed at which anomalies resolve indicates valve responsiveness.
Short rationale: Indicates valve responsiveness; purely mechanical.

Description: Very large anomalies reveal major bursts or uncontrolled discharge.
Short rationale: Major bursts/uncontrolled discharge; severity of event, not user behavior.

Description: Small but frequent anomalies suggest micro-leaks or slow-running fixtures.
Short rationale: Micro-leaks/slow fixtures; property condition with minimal behavior signal.

Description: Increased fluctuation amplitude indicates unstable water pressure.
Short rationale: Unstable pressure characterization; hydraulic only.

Description: Rapid flow escalation suggests sudden pipe failure.
Short rationale: Sudden flow escalation → pipe failure; structural risk.

Description: Sustained high-flow anomalies indicate continuous open flow like stuck toilet valves.
Short rationale: Continuous open flow (e.g., stuck toilet); some implicit fixture-use negligence.

Description: A spike above typical maximum flow implies water hammer or pump surges.
Short rationale: Water hammer/pump surges; physical phenomenon.

Description: Flow spikes followed by sudden drops suggest burst-pipe depressurization.
Short rationale: Burst-pipe depressurization; infrastructure health.

Description: Repeated anomaly shapes fingerprint specific appliance behaviors.
Short rationale: Appliance “fingerprints” reveal which appliances exist and how they run.

Description: Continuous abnormal flow during inactivity strongly indicates downstream leakage.
Short rationale: Continuous abnormal flow during inactivity encodes away/asleep windows and leak presence.

Description: Sudden sustained high-flow anomalies reflect catastrophic pipe rupture.
Short rationale: Catastrophic event; large property impact, little direct behavioral detail.

Description: Moderate continuous flow signals a stuck float or fill valve.
Short rationale: Shows faulty toilet hardware and moderate continuous use; weak behavior link.

Description: Flow anomalies that intensify over time suggest evolving leaks.
Short rationale: Leak evolution over time; asset degradation more than behavior.

Description: Large sustained flows followed by nonzero baselines indicate hose rupture.
Short rationale: Large sustained flow from hose; event severity, limited profiling.

Description: Anomalies during irrigation hours suggest faulty irrigation valves or pipes.
Short rationale: Irrigation-hour anomalies reveal outdoor watering schedules and habits.

Description: Reverse-flow signatures imply siphoning or back-pressure events.
Short rationale: Hydraulic backflow patterns; non-personal.

Description: Slow-start or slow-end anomalies imply partially stuck valves.
Short rationale: Partially stuck valves; mechanical.

Description: Wide anomaly magnitude variation suggests regulator malfunction.
Short rationale: Regulator malfunction; system state only.

Description: Mild, long-term anomalies indicate subterranean leakage.
Short rationale: Subterranean leakage; site-specific vulnerability, minimal behavioral info.

Description: Fewer anomalies during absence and more during presence reveal occupancy rhythms.
Short rationale: Directly reconstructs presence/absence and daily occupancy rhythms.

Description: Sudden increases in anomalies correlate with increased household activity.
Short rationale: Spikes during gatherings reveal social events and unusual high-activity periods.

Description: Continuous anomalies show taps left open or incomplete appliance cycles.
Short rationale: Continuous anomalies from unattended fixtures show forgetfulness and time-of-neglect patterns.

Description: Nighttime anomalies suggest tampering or unauthorized consumption.
Short rationale: Strong security/privacy signal: tampering or use during “should be idle” times.

Description: Recurring small anomalies at certain periods reflect accidental fixture use.
Short rationale: Encodes presence and behavior patterns of children (a sensitive household attribute).

Description: Clusters of anomalies correspond to high-water-use cleaning activity.
Short rationale: Clusters tied to cleaning routines reveal household chore schedules.

Description: Absence of anomalies during known vacancy validates occupancy status.
Short rationale: Confirms periods of full vacancy; serious security/occupancy implication.

Description: Repeating high-flow surges indicate a failing or cycling pump.
Short rationale: Repeating high-flow surges from pump; mechanical.

Description: Tiny rapid spikes reflect vibration-induced micro-flow.
Short rationale: Tiny rapid spikes when machinery runs; weak signal of equipment use timing.

Description: Intermittent anomalies followed by flow reduction suggest sediment shifts.
Short rationale: Sediment-related anomalies; hydraulic.

Description: High initial anomaly then decreasing flow indicates filter clogging.
Short rationale: Filter clogging pattern; maintenance state only.

Description: Short anomaly bursts reflect trapped air being expelled.
Short rationale: Trapped air events; non-personal.

Description: Rapid extreme spikes indicate pressure shock events.
Short rationale: Pressure shock behavior; structural.

Description: Increasing anomaly count over time reflects weakening pipelines.
Short rationale: Rising anomaly count over time; infrastructure age.

Description: Slow return to normal flow indicates valve or pressure lag.
Short rationale: Lag in returning to normal; valve/pressure characteristics.

Description: Faster recovery suggests anomalies near fixtures; slower recovery suggests upstream stress.
Short rationale: Localizes stress zone; network topology only.

Description: Repeated similar anomalies imply heavy usage in specific water branches.
Short rationale: Repeated anomalies in branches show which zones/rooms are heavy users.

Description: Unique anomaly curves reveal constriction effects from incorrect pipe sizing.
Short rationale: Reveals sizing issues; purely design/installation info.

Description: Two-step anomaly curves indicate water use across multiple floors.
Short rationale: Two-step curves show activity across floors (potentially different units/households).

Description: Persistent anomalies point to failures in major pipe branches.
Short rationale: Persistent anomalies in main branches; structural.

Description: Repetitive tiny anomalies during machinery operation suggest vibration transfer to pipes.
Short rationale: Links machinery operation to small anomalies; weak operational pattern.

Description: Longer anomaly duration correlates with greater distance to the main shutoff.
Short rationale: Estimates distance from anomaly to shutoff; physical layout.

Description: More anomalies in dry months imply irrigation-driven anomalies.
Short rationale: More anomalies in dry months show irrigation demand; mild behavior link.

Description: Sudden anomalies during cold weather indicate freeze-induced pipe cracking.
Short rationale: Cold-weather spikes; environmental stress on pipes.

Description: More anomalies during heat waves imply evaporative cooling or outdoor water use.
Short rationale: Anomalies during heat waves reveal increased outdoor/evaporative use patterns.

Description: Anomalies correlating with rain indicate soil-induced pipe pressure.
Short rationale: Correlation with rain/soil conditions; site vulnerability more than behavior.

Description: High-flow anomalies during unoccupied periods can indicate unauthorized usage.
Short rationale: High-flow anomalies when unoccupied strongly indicate theft/unauthorized use.

Description: Slow-tapering anomalies indicate gravity-fed drainage or runoff.
Short rationale: Gravity-fed drainage/runoff behavior; physical only.

Description: Unique anomaly spikes classify appliance types.
Short rationale: Classifies appliance types and use profiles, enabling lifestyle/device profiling.

Description: Rhythmic anomalies reveal pressure feedback issues.
Short rationale: Rhythmic anomalies from feedback; non-personal.

Description: Anomalies that increase but never reach high-flow thresholds indicate pipe constriction.
Short rationale: Constriction/partial blockage; hydraulic.

Description: Drop in anomaly frequency confirms repair success.
Short rationale: Confirms repair effectiveness; maintenance metadata only.

Description: Multi-peaked anomalies suggest concurrent fixture usage.
Short rationale: Multi-peaked anomalies show concurrent fixture usage and combined habits.

Description: Increasing anomaly unpredictability reflects declining hydraulic stability.
Short rationale: Declining hydraulic stability; system state.

Description: Changes in anomaly shape over time predict future failure probability.
Short rationale: Shape evolution as failure predictor; asset-health only.

Description: Repetitive oscillatory anomalies indicate resonance in pipes.
Short rationale: Resonance in pipes; mechanical.

Description: Gradually escalating anomaly severity suggests looming pipe failure.
Short rationale: Gradually escalating anomalies; structural risk.

Description: Very small repetitive anomalies reflect micro-cracks.
Short rationale: Very small repetitive anomalies from micro-cracks; minimal behavioral content.

Description: Anomalies during fixture use imply internal misalignment causing resistance.
Short rationale: Misaligned fixture internals; technical.

Description: Time-shifted anomaly waves indicate unusual pressure propagation paths.
Short rationale: Unusual pressure paths; network behavior.

Description: Anomalies during valve closing indicate imperfect seating.
Short rationale: Imperfect valve seating; mechanical.

Description: Reverse anomalies indicate siphoning or pressure collapse.
Short rationale: Reverse flow from siphoning/pressure collapse; hydraulic.

Description: Anomalies reveal tank fill cycles or overflow events.
Short rationale: Tank fill/overflow cycles; weakly reveals building-level usage cycles.

Description: Higher anomalies during peak usage imply wear-sensitive segments.
Short rationale: Points to segments stressed under peak usage → links wear to usage patterns.

Description: Baseline anomaly increases suggest growing internal stress.
Short rationale: Growing baseline stress; system health only.

Description: Irregular anomaly patterns indicate abnormal interaction between hot and cold lines.
Short rationale: Abnormal hot/cold line interaction; design/maintenance issue.
